title: Intel's GPU: The Hunt Begins...

And Linus is off that day. Coincidence? You have until then to find the GPUs or they will all explode. - [Crewmember] They didn't really do a good job with the coolers. - They actually explode, or they just get used for crypto? - [Crewmember] Made that up. - Oh, okay. It seems like a lot of work for a little game that'll probably just unlock another video teaser for another graphics card we won't be able to buy. Sorry, it's been a tough year, I'm jaded now. I'm cynical. - [Crewmember] Yeah. - In other GPU news, AMD says they won't be adopting NVIDIA's clumsy strategy of limiting certain graphics cards' mining efficiency, since it's now been shown that a single leaked driver can screw it all up. The news comes from a product manager at AMD who told PC Gamer that the company's current gen cards, based on the RDNA 2 architecture, aren't really that great for mining anyway. Although AMD's Linux-based drivers are open source and therefore open to manipulation. I guess we'll have to wait and see whether miners jump on AMD's next GPU release, which at least one leaker thinks may come in April in the form of a premium 1080p gaming card. That's our card, miners. - [Crewmember] Hey! - That's for us. - [Crewmember] Stop it. - You leave it alone. You stop it. - [Crewmember] Drop that card. - Drop it. (bullets fire rapidly) And AT&T thought they were pretty cool launching HBO Max and giving Zack Snyder a platform to finish his version of that movie. They're not cool enough to break California's net neutrality laws. The network provider will no longer exempt its users' HBO Max usage from their mobile data caps, a practice called zero rating, after a California law went into effect last month preventing ISPs from giving preferential treatment to their own video platforms. Take that vertical integration. - [Crewmember] Ta-da! - In a statement AT&T said the law prohibits them from providing certain free features to consumers but that's not true. It would be perfectly legal to zero rate all video services, including Netflix and Prime Video, which of course they won't do 'cause they don't own them. It seems like discussions about net neutrality are on the rise once again. A number of tech companies including Mozilla, Reddit, Wikimedia, and Vimeo called on the FCC to reinstate the commissions net neutrality rules repealed by the Trump administration which is fine, but who neutralizes the net neutralizers? - [Crewmember] Oh! - You know. That's what I'd like to see discussed. - [Crewmember] Yeah. - The Watchmen, too. - [Crewmember] (laughs) Snyder, we need you. (James laughs) - (echoing) Riley? But you're over there.
